action.action-desc: Mr. Mulvaney introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 to provide requirements that must be followed by the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection when carrying out certain examinations.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Bureau Examination Fairness Act.

subsection.text: The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended by inserting after section 1026 the following:
The Bureau may not include enforcement attorneys when performing examinations pursuant to section 1024, 1025, or 1026.
In any request for data from an entity supervised by the Bureau pursuant to section 1024, 1025, or 1026, the Bureau shall—

paragraph.text: ensure that the different divisions of the Bureau coordinate with each other before the data is requested;
accompany each request with a written statement of intended use for the data being requested;
use peer-reviewed data sampling based on limited data sets rather than requesting full data sets, unless the Director determines, in writing, that requesting full data sets is necessary; and

with respect to a data request with respect to which the Bureau anticipates the cost of complying with such request will exceed $50,000 per company, provide the entity with the written approval of the Director for such request.

subsection.text: When respect to an examination conducted by the Bureau, the Bureau shall—

paragraph.text: complete the examination field work and conduct an exit interview with the entity being examined not later than the end of the 60-day period beginning on the date the examination begins; and
produce a report of examination or supervisory letter—

subparagraph.text: not later than the end of the 120-day period beginning on the date the examination is completed; or

subsection.text: The Bureau may only perform one limited-scope examination of an entity at any one time.
